DayItem.Title: Questions to the Chancellor of the Exchequer
Topical Questions to the Chancellor of the Exchequer

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: Bill to establish the Independent Football Regulator; to make provision for the licensing of football clubs; to make provision about the distribution of revenue received by organisers of football competitions; and for connected purposes.

DayItem.Title: Illegal and unsustainable fishing (due diligence): Ten Minute Rule Motion

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: The Member moving and a Member opposing this Motion may each speak for up to 10 minutes.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That leave be given to bring in a Bill to require suppliers and retailers of fish and related products to establish and implement due diligence systems to ensure that those products are not obtained from illegal or unsustainable fishing; and for connected purposes.

DayItem.Title: TRADE (COMPREHENSIVE AND PROGRESSIVE AGREEMENT FOR TRANS-PACIFIC PARTNERSHIP) BILL [LORDS]: REMAINING STAGES

BusinessItemDetail.Notes:
Proceedings on Consideration will (so far as not previously concluded) be brought to a conclusion at 6.00pm. Proceedings on Third Reading will (so far as not previously concluded) be brought to a conclusion at 7.00pm (Order of 29 January).

The Scottish Parliament has passed a legislative consent resolution relating to this Bill. Copies of the Resolution are available in the Vote Office (also available on the documents webpage for the Bill).
BusinessItemDetail.RelevantDocuments:
Second Report of the Business and Trade Committee, UK accession to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership, HC 483

Oral evidence taken before the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Committee on 21 November 2023, 6 February and 27 February 2024, on UK trade policy: food and agriculture, HC 162
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: Not amended in Public Bill Committee, to be considered.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 7.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the draft Reporting on Payment Practices and Performance (Amendment) Regulations 2024, which were laid before this House on 10 January, be approved.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 7.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the draft National Minimum Wage (Amendment) (No. 2) Regulations 2024, which were laid before this House on 31 January, be approved.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes:
The Delegated Legislation Committee is scheduled to meet at 9.25am today.

If this item is opposed after 7.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.Duration: No debate (if the Delegated Legislation Committee has reported)
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the draft Strategy and Policy Statement for Energy Policy in Great Britain, which was laid before this House on 21 February, be approved.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes:
The Delegated Legislation Committee is scheduled to meet at 9.25am today.

If this item is opposed after 7.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.Duration: No debate (if the Delegated Legislation Committee has reported)
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the draft Fair Dealing Obligations (Milk) Regulations 2024, which were laid before this House on 1 March, be approved.

StandingOrder.Text: Standing Order No. 118(6) and Order of 5 March

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 7.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That this House authorises the Secretary of State to undertake to pay, and to pay by way of financial assistance under section 8 of the Industrial Development Act 1982, a grant or grants exceeding £30 million and up to a total of £75 million to BMW to support the production of electric Minis at Plant Oxford.

DayItem.Title: Traffic congestion and road safety in Rother Valley
Recommendations of the Infected Blood Inquiry

BusinessItemDetail.Duration: Until 7.30pm or for half an hour (whichever is later)

DayItem.Title: Order of Business
DayItem.Notes: The first part of the sitting will last for two hours. The second part of the sitting will last for three hours (Standing Order No. 10(1)).

DayItem.Title: That this House has considered tutoring provision

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: The subject for this debate was determined by the Backbench Business Committee.

DayItem.Title: That this House has considered UK food security

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: The sitting will be suspended from 11.30am to 2.30pm.
BusinessItemDetail.RelevantDocuments: Seventh Report of the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Committee of Session 2022–23, Food Security, HC 622, and the Government response, Session 2023–24, HC 37

DayItem.Title: That this House has considered international support for Armenian refugees from Nagorno-Karabakh
That this House has considered baby loss and the role of coroners
That this House has considered Child Trust Fund access for people seeking to manage the finances of others

BusinessItemDetail.Notes:
The debate at 4.30pm will last for up to an hour.

The sitting will be suspended and time added if divisions take place in the main Chamber (Standing Order No. 10(3)).
BusinessItemDetail.RelevantDocuments: Sixty-Seventh Report of the Committee of Public Accounts of Session 2022–23, Child Trust Funds, HC 1231, and the Government response, CP 941

DayItem.Title: Post Office: continuing Horizon Inquiry participation costs
Government response to the Public Inquiry into Brook House immigration removal centre
Update on the anticipated acquisition of Telegraph Media Group Limited
Forthcoming End of Day Adjournment Debates

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: Applications for 30-minute end of day adjournment debates should be made to the Table Office by 7.00pm or rise of the House, whichever is the earlier, on the Wednesdays listed below. Members can submit their application via MemberHub, from their own email account or in hard copy. Application forms are available on the Table Office page on ParliNet. The ballot takes place on the day following the deadline. Members who are successful will be contacted by the Speaker’s Office.

DayItem.Title: Monday 15 to Monday 22 April (deadline Wednesday 20 March 7.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)
Tuesday 23 to Monday 29 April (deadline Wednesday 17 April 7.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)
Tuesday 30 April to Thursday 2 May (deadline Wednesday 24 April 7.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)
Tuesday 7 to Monday 13 May (deadline Wednesday 1 May 7.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: The rota for answering Departments is listed below. Applications for 90, 60 and 30-minute debates should be made to the Table Office by 10.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is the earlier, on the Mondays listed below. Members can submit their application via MemberHub, from their own email account or in hard copy. Application forms are available on the Table Office page on ParliNet. The ballot takes place on the day following the deadline. Members who are successful will be contacted by the Speaker's Office.
The ballot for Tuesday 26 March will take place today. The deadline for making an application to this ballot has now passed.

DayItem.Title: Tuesday 16 and Wednesday 17 April (deadline Monday 25 March 10.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText:
The following Departments will answer: 

Attorney General; Cabinet Office; Defence; Education; Environment, Food and Rural Affairs; Foreign, Commonwealth and Development; Health and Social Care; Justice; Levelling Up, Housing and Communities; Northern Ireland; Wales

DayItem.Title: Tuesday 23 and Wednesday 24 April (deadline Monday 15 April 10.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText:
The following Departments will answer: 

Business and Trade; Culture, Media and Sport; Energy Security and Net Zero; Home Office; Science, Innovation and Technology; Scotland; Transport; Treasury; Women and Equalities; Work and Pensions
